name: Poseidon
shortDescription: God of the Sea, Earthquakes, and Horses
fullDescription: Poseidon (Greek: Œ†ŒøœÉŒµŒπŒ¥·ø∂ŒΩ) is one of the three great sons of Kronos who divided the cosmos, commanding the vast oceans, shaking the earth with his mighty trident, and credited with creating the first horses. Known as the Earth-Shaker (Ennosigaios) and Lord of the Seas, he embodies the dual nature of water itself: life-giving sustenance and terrifying destruction. Born as one of the children swallowed by his father Kronos and later freed when Zeus forced the Titan to regurgitate his siblings, Poseidon played a crucial role in the Titanomachy. After the Olympians' victory, the three brothers drew lots to divide the conquered cosmos‚ÄîZeus claimed the sky, Hades the underworld, and Poseidon received dominion over all seas, lakes, rivers, and springs. From his magnificent palace beneath the waves, Poseidon wields the golden trident forged by the Cyclopes, capable of summoning storms, creating earthquakes, and stirring the depths. His temperament mirrors the sea itself: generous and life-sustaining to those who honor him, but devastating to those who earn his wrath. Sailors, fishermen, and coastal peoples throughout the ancient world revered this powerful deity. Poseidon's many unions with nymphs, goddesses, and mortals produced both heroic children (including Theseus, Athens' greatest hero) and monstrous offspring (including the Cyclops Polyphemus and the winged horse Pegasus), reflecting the sea's dual creative and destructive nature.

properties.name: Greek Titles
properties.value: Petraios (of Rocks), Hippios (of Horses), Ennosigaios (Earth-Shaker), Gaieochos (Holder of the Earth), Asphalios (Steadfast)

properties.name: Domains
properties.value: Seas, oceans, storms, earthquakes, horses, navigation, floods, springs, coastal regions

properties.name: Symbols
properties.value: Trident, dolphins, horses, bull, chariot, anchor, fish, seashells

properties.name: Sacred Animals
properties.value: Horse, dolphin, bull, hippocampus (sea-horse), fish, ram

properties.name: Colors
properties.value: Sea blue, teal, ocean green, deep navy, white foam

properties.name: Sacred Sites
properties.value: Cape Sounion, Isthmus of Corinth, Helike, Tainaron

mythologyContexts.usage: Supreme ruler of all waters; controller of earthquakes and storms; creator of horses; protector of sailors and fishermen; one of the three divine brothers who rule the cosmos; patron of several Greek cities and competitor for others

textReferences.context: Poseidon's intervention in the Trojan War; his rivalry with Zeus; building Troy's walls
Poseidon's wrath against Odysseus for blinding Polyphemus; ten-year persecution
Poseidon's birth and the division of the cosmos
Praise of Poseidon as earth-shaker and tamer of horses
Poseidon's various myths, children, and contests with other gods
Cult sites, temples, and worship practices of Poseidon

mythologyContexts.symbolism: Poseidon's trident represents his three-fold dominion: the sea, earthquakes, and horses. Each prong symbolizes a different aspect of his power. The dolphin represents his benevolent side‚Äîintelligent, helpful, and guiding sailors safely. The horse embodies his creative power and connection to the earth (through earthquakes). The bull reflects his raw strength and tempestuous nature. His association with both calm waters and devastating storms makes him a complex deity representing nature's duality. As Earth-Shaker, Poseidon reminds mortals that solid ground itself is subject to divine power. The saltwater spring he created on the Acropolis symbolizes his gifts being powerful but not always practical‚Äîcontrasting with Athena's useful olive tree. His underwater palace represents the hidden depths and mysteries of the ocean, a realm as vast and complex as the heavens but far more unknowable to mortals.
mythologyContexts.culturalSignificance: Poseidon was central to Greek maritime civilization. Sailors poured libations to him before every voyage and dedicated temples at crucial coastal points like Cape Sounion. The Isthmian Games, one of the four great pan-Hellenic festivals, honored Poseidon every two years with athletic and equestrian competitions. His contest with Athena for Athens became a founding myth of Athenian identity, with the olive tree (Athena's gift) symbolizing civilization and wisdom over raw power (Poseidon's saltwater spring). The god's association with horses made him patron of chariot racing and cavalry. Earthquake-prone regions particularly honored him as Asphaleios (Steadfast), seeking protection from seismic destruction. The destruction of Helike by earthquake and tsunami in 373 BCE was interpreted as divine punishment for sacrilege against Poseidon. His transformation into Roman Neptune extended his worship throughout the Mediterranean. Modern language preserves Poseidon in Neptune (planet), nautical terminology, and countless cultural references to sea gods and ocean power.

archetypes.name: The Sea God
examples: Supreme ruler of all seas, oceans, and waters
Controls storms, tides, and sea creatures
Protector of sailors and fishermen
Embodiment of the sea's dual nature‚Äîlife-giving and destructive
Commands the depths and all marine life
archetypes.context: Poseidon is the archetypal Sea God in Western mythology‚Äîthe absolute sovereign of the ocean realm whose power over water is matched only by Zeus's control of the sky.

archetypes.name: The Earth Shaker
examples: Causes earthquakes by striking the earth with his trident
Known as Ennosigaios (Earth-Shaker)
Can topple cities and reshape coastlines
Reminds mortals that even solid ground is subject to divine power
Punishes cities and peoples through seismic devastation
archetypes.context: As the Earth-Shaker, Poseidon embodies the terrifying power of earthquakes and natural catastrophe, demonstrating that divine power extends beyond his primary ocean domain.

archetypes.name: The Horse Lord
examples: Created the first horse from sea foam or striking rock
Known as Hippios (of Horses)
Patron of horse racing and equestrian arts
Father of famous horses including the winged Pegasus
Rides chariot drawn by hippocampi (horse-fish hybrids)
archetypes.context: Poseidon's creation and mastery of horses connects him to land-based power and makes him patron of cavalry, charioteers, and horse tamers.

archetypes.name: The Temperamental Deity
examples: Mood as changeable as the sea itself
Quick to anger and slow to forgive (as with Odysseus)
Capable of great benevolence or devastating wrath
Competitive and resentful when slighted (Athens, Troy)
Reflects the unpredictable nature of the ocean
archetypes.context: Poseidon embodies the archetype of the temperamental deity whose shifting moods mirror the elements he controls‚Äîcalm and generous one moment, wrathful and destructive the next.

etymology.meaning: Uncertain; possibly 'Husband of Da' (earth goddess) or 'Lord of Waters'
etymology.derivation: Etymology debated. Possibly from 'posis' (husband/lord) + 'de/da' (earth), making him originally an earth-spouse deity. Alternative: from 'potei' (to rule) + 'dan' (water). Pre-Greek origin also possible given Bronze Age attestation.

cognates.meaning: Roman sea god (originally fresh water deity)

cultCenters.name: Cape Sounion
cultCenters.description: Dramatic clifftop temple overlooking the Aegean

cultCenters.name: Helike
cultCenters.description: Major cult center destroyed by earthquake/tsunami 373 BCE
